questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the physician for gradually increasing confusion and difficulty walking for the past 4 months. Her daughter is concerned because she has been forgetful and seems to be walking more slowly. She has been distracted during her weekly bridge games and her usual television shows. She has also had increasingly frequent episodes of urinary incontinence and now wears an adult diaper daily. She has hyperlipidemia and hypertension. Current medications include lisinopril and atorvastatin. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 139/83 mmHg. She is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. She has a broad-based gait and takes short steps. Sensation is intact and muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Laboratory studies are within normal limits. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy-bodies (DLB) is characterized by early impairments in attention and executive function, with memory impairment developing later in the disease course. In addition, diagnosis requires two of the following: cognitive fluctuations (episodes of worse cognition and alertness interspersed with periods of relatively normal function), visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism. While this patient demonstrates cognitive impairment and a slow gait with short steps, she does not have any other features of parkinsonism, e.g., tremor or rigidity. Also, the patient lacks visual hallucinations or cognitive fluctuations.

B) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia, with increasing prevalence after 60 years of age. Memory impairment is the cardinal and most common initial symptom, while behavioral symptoms, primitive reflexes, and urinary incontinence may present late in the disease course. The early development of urinary incontinence and gait disturbances in this patient is not typical of Alzheimer disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Pseudodementia is characterized by cognitive deficits and memory impairment that may mimic dementia. It is important to consider in older patients, as cognitive deficits may resolve with treatment of the related psychiatric condition (most commonly depression). Although this patient has recent behavioral changes that may be interpreted as anhedonia, she has difficulty staying focused rather than decreased interest. This patient does not meet other criteria for major depression, and pseudodementia is not typically associated with gait disturbances or incontinence.

D) INCORRECT:

The hallmarks of frontotemporal dementia (FTD) are early, progressive aphasia or behavior and personality changes (e.g., disinhibition, apathy, hyperorality, and compulsive behaviors), which occurs alongside degeneration of the frontal and/or temporal lobes. FTD typically presents on average during the fifth decade of life, making it a relatively common cause of early-onset dementia. While this patient's performance on the five-minute recall test generally raises suspicion for the presence of dementia, the lack of language dysfunction or personality changes, the patient's age, and the presence of gait abnormalities make FTD an unlikely diagnosis.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

E) CORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) manifests with gait instability, cognitive disturbance, and urinary incontinence – the classic “wet, wacky, and wobbly” triad. Gait changes are typically symmetrical, while cognitive impairment primarily manifests as decreased attention span and concentration, without psychotic features that may be characteristic of other causes of dementia. (See table “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia”).
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

F) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency develops after years of inadequate intake, malabsorption, or increased demand. The condition can manifest with symptoms such as memory impairment, personality changes, and paresthesias, which could lead to incontinence and gait abnormalities. However, vitamin B12 deficiency typically results in loss of distal vibratory sense in the extremities (lower > upper), and (megaloblastic) anemia is an expected finding on laboratory evaluation.

G) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for vascular dementia include hypertension and dyslipidemia. Its clinical presentation is highly variable as different regions of the brain may be involved in the vascular insults that lead to cognitive deterioration. Symptoms can include gait disturbances, urinary frequency, personality and mood changes, and cognitive deficits, as well as cortical symptoms such as aphasia or amnesia. However, vascular dementia is associated clinically with the development of deficits in a stepwise manner, and not gradual development as in this patient. Moreover, exacerbations associated with vascular events may be clinically apparent, e.g., as unprovoked falls in the patient's history, or as signs of stroke on examination.

H) INCORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is characterized by progressive dementia and visual/cerebellar disturbances, which could be consistent with this patient's gait instability and memory impairment. However, CJD typically progresses very rapidly and is associated with additional symptoms of myoclonus (present in > 90% of patients), pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction, and akinetic mutism, all of which are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's confusion, gait apraxia, and urinary incontinence constitute the classic triad of a condition associated with reversible dementia in older adults.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the physician because of difficulty walking for the past year. He reports that his gait has become slower and that initiating steps has become more challenging. During the past 6 months, his family has noticed that he is starting to forget important family meetings and holidays. On a number of occasions, he has not been able to get to the bathroom in time in order to urinate. He has hypertension treated with hydrochlorothiazide. His father died of Parkinson disease at the age of 63 years. The patient had smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 40 years, but quit 10 years ago. His vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, he is confused and has short-term memory deficits. He has a wide-based, shuffling gait. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?

choices.text: Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the temporal lobe

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gradual-onset, mild forgetfulness, hesitant gait, and urinary incontinence may be normal consequences of aging, with risk increasing with advancing age. However, the severity and relative rapidity of this patient's symptoms are unlikely to be part of normal aging. Additionally, this patient's cranial MRI is abnormal.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased CSF production (due to choroid plexus neoplasia or inflammation) is a rare cause of communicating hydrocephalus. While communicating hydrocephalus also causes enlarged ventricles, it typically manifests with signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g, headache, nausea, vomiting) rather than the symptoms seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Degeneration of the substantia nigra is a hallmark of Parkinson disease (PD), which causes a characteristic shuffling, short-stepping gait. While this patient is at increased risk of PD given his family history, urinary incontinence and dementia are typically late findings of advanced PD. If this patient had advanced PD, he would have had other earlier signs of the disease (e.g., muscle rigidity, resting tremor, mask-like facies, etc.) for years preceding his current symptoms. Additionally, PD does not explain this patient's abnormal cranial MRI.

D) INCORRECT:

Frontotemporal brain atrophy is characteristic of frontotemporal dementia (FTD), which typically presents early on with aphasia and personality changes. This patient's prominent motor/urinary symptoms without substantial personality changes make FTD less likely. Moreover, his cranial MRI does not show frontotemporal atrophy and instead suggests another diagnosis.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

E) CORRECT:

Impaired CSF absorption (either idiopathic or due to dysfunction of the arachnoid villi) is the suspected underlying pathophysiologic mechanism of NPH. Impaired CSF absorption leads to transiently elevated intracranial pressure, which causes ventricular enlargement and compression of cerebral structures (e.g., corona radiata). Once the ventricles enlarge, homeostasis between CSF production and resorption is established and intracranial pressure normalizes.

CSF shunting is the main treatment for NPH. The next step in the management of this patient should be to perform a lumbar tap test. Improvement of symptoms after CSF removal strongly supports the diagnosis of NPH and suggests a favorable response to CSF shunting.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

F) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of CSF flow causes non-communicating hydrocephalus. While non-communicating hydrocephalus also causes enlarged ventricles, it typically manifests with signs of intracranial hypertension (e.g, headache, nausea, vomiting) rather than the symptoms seen in this patient. In addition, evidence of an obstructive mass would likely be seen on this patient's cranial MRI.
Image Description:

Cranial CT (axial view) of a 13-year-old boy

A large, liquor-like, hypodense lesion (red area) is located in the posterior cranial fossa in images 1–3. This lesion is most likely an arachnoid cyst compressing the cerebral aqueduct (A), which prevents the free circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space. As a result, the third ventricle (III) and the lateral ventricles (hatched area) are dilated, and there is transependymal egress of CSF (green shaded area, images 4 and 5).

C = cistern of great cerebral vein
T = inferior horn of the lateral ventricle

G) INCORRECT:

Degeneration of cholinergic neurons in the temporal lobe is found in Alzheimer disease (AD), which commonly causes memory difficulties and enlarged ventricles on cranial MRI. Gait changes and urinary incontinence are typically found in advanced AD years after diagnosis. However, this patient's rapid onset and progression of memory and gait changes associated with urinary incontinence is unlikely to be caused by AD. Moreover, AD usually causes cerebral atrophy (particularly of the hippocampus and temporal lobe), which is not seen on this patient's MRI.
Image Description:

MRI head (T2-weighted; axial plane) of a patient with increasing memory disturbance

Bilateral cerebral atrophy with prominent Sylvian fissures (green overlay) is seen.

1: caudate nucleus; 2: putamen; 3: thalamus

H) INCORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is a rare cause of rapidly progressive dementia. While CJD can also cause ataxia and a resulting wide-based gait, more than 90% of patients present with myoclonus and the condition is commonly associated with other neuropsychiatric symptoms such as hallucinations and depression. Also, this patient's MRI shows ventriculomegaly, which is more consistent with another diagnosis.
Image Description:

MRI head (left: T2-weighted image, axial plane; right: diffusion-weighted image (DWI), axial plane) of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)

The DWI shows hyperintensities (examples indicated by arrows) in the putamen (red overlay), thalamus (yellow overlay), and caudate nucleus (green overlay), common locations for deep gray matter involvement with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD may also demonstrate ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri (cortical ribboning; not shown). A probable diagnosis of CJD can be made when expected MR imaging patterns are seen and CJD-mimicking disorders are confidently ruled out clinically.

I) INCORRECT:

Multiple brain infarctions are characteristic of vascular dementia, which is the second most common form of dementia. This patient is at increased risk of developing vascular dementia given his history of smoking and hypertension, and symptom onset in vascular dementia may be relatively rapid. However, this patient's MRI does not show the expected signs of ischemia (e.g., multiple infarcts), and a stepwise decline in function would be more typical of vascular dementia.
Image Description:

CT head (without contrast; axial plane)

Abnormal low attenuation areas (green overlay) are seen in the periventricular white matter. Two frontal lacunar infarcts (arrowheads) are also present.

These findings may be seen in vascular dementia.
questions.hint: The combination of gait abnormalities, dementia, urinary incontinence, and ventriculomegaly without sulcal enlargement in MRI highly suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the physician by his parents for the evaluation of progressive enlargement of his head circumference. His parents report that he has been healthy except for an episode of tonsillitis 3 months ago treated with penicillin. The patient was born at term by a lower segment transverse cesarean delivery because of a transverse lie. He has met all developmental milestones. His immunizations are up-to-date. The patient is at the 50th percentile for length, 50th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. He appears well-nourished. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 120/min, and blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diuretics such as furosemide decrease CSF production and are sometimes used as temporary therapy in patients too unstable to undergo surgery. However, imaging is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Although serial lumbar punctures were used in the past as a temporary measure in preterm infants with posthemorrhagic hydrocephalus as a complication of intraventricular hemorrhage, the procedure is no longer recommended. Imaging is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Although imaging is necessary to confirm the diagnosis, CT would expose this young patient to unnecessary radiation. CT scan may be indicated in older children in an acute setting to quickly identify the cause of increased intracranial pressure and in adults with suspected hydrocephalus.

D) INCORRECT:

CSF shunts are a definitive treatment for hydrocephalus. However, before proceeding with a surgical intervention, neuroimaging is required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

E) CORRECT:

A patient with hydrocephalus requires neuroimaging to determine the extent of the condition and the underlying cause. Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality in newborns and young infants in whom the anterior fontanelle is still open because it allows direct visualization of the brain. Moreover, ultrasound does not involve radiation and does not require sedation of the patient.

Although standard MRI is safe for infants, sedation is required, making it less appropriate than ultrasonography. Ultra-fast MRI techniques, however, do not require infant sedation and can be used as an alternative to ultrasonography. MRI is the preferred imaging modality in older children in whom the anterior fontanelle has closed (it usually closes at 12–18 months of age).
questions.hint: This patient presents with macrocephaly, tense fontanelle, and a sunset eye sign, all of which suggest hydrocephalus.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician for a well-child examination. His mother is concerned because he is unable to walk on his own. He has been increasingly irritable over the past month, has been feeding poorly, and has had multiple episodes of vomiting. His immunizations are up-to-date. He is at the 50th percentile for height, 40th percentile for weight, and 98th percentile for head circumference. He appears lethargic. His vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows a bulging anterior fontanelle. The child is unable to stand without support and falls if he attempts to walk. Muscle tone is increased and deep tendon reflexes are 4+ in the lower extremities. Examination of the back is unremarkable. An MRI of the brain shows symmetrical enlargement of all four ventricles. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cerebral aqueductoplasty may be used to treat obstructive hydrocephalus caused by stenosis of the aqueduct of Sylvius. Congenital stenosis of the aqueduct of Sylvius would present similarly, but the fourth ventricle would not be dilated with enlargement of all four ventricles.

B) CORRECT:

A ventriculoperitoneal shunt, which diverts excess CSF from the ventricles to the peritoneal cavity, is the standard of care to decrease intracranial pressure in children with communicating hydrocephalus. Although spinal taps and the use of certain diuretics (e.g., furosemide, acetazolamide) may quickly decrease ICP, these measures are not effective in preventing the progression of hydrocephalus over the long term.

C) INCORRECT:

Although furosemide may decrease CSF production and intracranial pressure, it is less effective than standard therapy in decreasing ICP. Furosemide may be used temporarily in patients who are too unstable for standard therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Although acetazolamide may decrease CSF production and intracranial pressure, it is less effective than standard therapy in decreasing ICP. Acetazolamide may be used temporarily in patients who are too unstable for the treatment of choice.

E) INCORRECT:

Studies have shown that serial lumbar punctures are not effective in preventing the progression of hydrocephalus. Frequent spinal taps also increase the risk of infection. Serial lumbar punctures may be used in preterm infants until they are large enough for the definitive treatment.
questions.hint: Irritability, poor feeding, vomiting, delayed gross motor milestones, upper motor neuron signs (increased muscle tone and hyperreflexia), macrocephaly, and a bulging anterior fontanelle are consistent with increased intracranial pressure (ICP). An MRI showing symmetrical enlargement of all 4 ventricles indicate a symptomatic, communicating hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of several episodes of urinary incontinence over the past several months. She reports that she was not able to get to the bathroom in time. During the past 6 months, her husband has noticed that she is starting to forget important appointments and family meetings. She has type 2 diabetes mellitus treated with metformin. The patient had smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 45 years. Her vital signs are within normal limits. On mental status examination, she is confused and has short-term memory deficits. She walks slowly taking short, wide steps. Muscle strength is normal. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's urinary incontinence?

choices.text: Bacterial infection of the urinary tract

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A urinary tract infection could cause incontinence. Pre-existing diabetes mellitus and dementia (which could possibly cause poor personal hygiene) both increase the risk of infection in this patient. However, the absence of typical features of infection, such as fever and dysuria, make this a highly unlikely underlying cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Detrusor-sphincter dyssynergia is the underlying mechanism of reflex incontinence, which is characterized by unpredictable urinary leakage that occurs when the bladder is full or otherwise stimulated (e.g., by cold air). This patient has no such condition and exhibits an awareness of the desire for urinary expulsion (as evidenced by her failed attempts at getting to the bathroom), making this an unlikely underlying cause.

C) CORRECT:

The symptoms of NPH are caused by an underlying compression of the periventricular white matter tracts. This effect causes a loss of central inhibition of the detrusor muscle, leading to a strong voiding reflex that cannot be suppressed (urge incontinence). The urge incontinence is potentially exacerbated by the functional frontal lobe impairment that results from compression, which prevents recognition of the urinary urge. Additionally, the presence of gait disturbances makes getting to the toilet more difficult and leads to further incontinence-related issues.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

D) INCORRECT:

A loss of sphincter function would cause total incontinence, which is characterized by urinary leakage that continuously occurs, with no associated preceding symptoms or specific trigger activity. Since this patient has episodic urinary loss rather than continuous leakage, this option is an unlikely underlying cause. Total incontinence is likely to occur in patients with a history of spinal dysfunction (due to previous surgery, trauma, nerve damage, metastasis) or abnormal anatomy (fistula).

E) INCORRECT:

Urethral hypermobility is one of the most common causes of stress incontinence, which is common in postmenopausal women. However, this patient has no features to suggest this diagnosis (i.e., negative Q-tip test, leakage of urine with coughing).

F) INCORRECT:

Impaired detrusor contractility is the underlying mechanism of overflow incontinence, which is characterized by frequent, involuntary dribbling of urine that occurs when the bladder is full and is not associated with a specific urge. This patient exhibits an awareness of the desire for urinary expulsion (as evidenced by her failed attempts at getting to the bathroom), making this an unlikely underlying cause.
questions.hint: This patient presents with the classic triad of urinary incontinence (wet), dementia (wacky), and gait abnormalities (wobbly), which suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

questions.text: A 74-year-old woman is brought to the physician by her daughter for worsening memory for the past 1 month. She can no longer manage her bills and frequently forgets the names of her children. Her daughter is also concerned that her mother has a urinary tract infection because she has had increased urinary urgency and several episodes of urinary incontinence. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows poor short-term memory recall and a slow gait with wide, short steps. Which of the following is most likely to improve this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents a risk of permanent neurological damage, due to compression of periventricular white matter from ventricular distention. Even removal of a small amount of CSF via a lumbar puncture can be helpful but the definitive treatment of normal pressure hydrocephalus usually involves the drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (e.g., VP shunt).
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

B) INCORRECT:

Prescription of bromocriptine is used in the treatment of Parkinson disease. Though patients with Parkinson disease may show gait abnormalities, this patient's gait abnormalities (wide, short steps) are inconsistent with the characteristic Parkinson gait and her triad of symptoms suggest underlying NPH.

C) INCORRECT:

Prescription of donepezil, a cholinesterase inhibitor, is an established treatment for mild to moderate Alzheimer disease or vascular dementia. Although this patient does show signs of dementia, her cognitive symptoms only developed recently and manifest alongside urinary incontinence, which would not be expected until the late stages of Alzheimer disease. In addition, gait abnormalities are not a typical feature of Alzheimer disease.

D) INCORRECT:

Prescription of ciprofloxacin can be used for the treatment of UTI. Although urinary incontinence can be a symptom of UTI, this diagnosis would not explain this patient's other symptoms of normal pressure hydrocephalus (e.g., dementia, gait abnormalities).

E) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy can help improve symptoms of incontinence caused by decreased pelvic floor support and subsequent pelvic organ prolapse (POP), as well as help decrease falls in older individuals. However, physical therapy alone would not address the underlying etiology of this woman's symptoms due to NPH.

F) INCORRECT:

Placement of a vaginal pessary can be helpful in the treatment of urinary incontinence due to pelvic organ prolapse and could theoretically provide some symptomatic relief for the urinary incontinence in this post-menopausal woman. It would not, however, help in the treatment of her other symptoms of normal pressure hydrocephalus (e.g., dementia, gait abnormalities).
questions.hint: Apraxic (“magnetic”) gait, dementia, and incontinence are the classic triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for increased forgetfulness and unsteady gait over the past 3 months. He is a journalist and has had difficulty concentrating on his writing. He also complains of urinary urgency recently. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F) and blood pressure is 139/83 mm Hg. He is oriented only to person and place. He is able to recall 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. He has a slow, broad-based gait and takes short steps. Neurological examination is otherwise normal. Urinalysis is normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia, with increasing prevalence after 60 years of age. Memory impairment is the cardinal and most common initial symptom, while behavioral symptoms, primitive reflexes, and urinary incontinence may manifest late in the disease course. The early development of gait disturbances in this patient is not typical of Alzheimer disease.

B) CORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) manifests with gait instability, cognitive disturbance, and urinary incontinence – the classic “wet, wacky, and wobbly” triad. Gait changes are typically symmetrical, while cognitive impairment primarily takes the form of decreased attention span and concentration. NPH is an important diagnosis to consider in a patient with dementia, as it may be reversible if the hydrocephalus is addressed (e.g., with a lumbar puncture to remove CSF). In most patients > 60 years of age, the accumulation of CSF is idiopathic, but it may also occur due to secondary causes (e.g., inflammation, hemorrhage) that lead to obstruction of the subarachnoid villi that normally resorb CSF in the ventricular system.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

C) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for vascular dementia include hypertension and dyslipidemia. Its clinical presentation is highly variable, as different regions of the brain may be involved in the vascular insults that lead to cognitive deterioration. Symptoms can include gait disturbances, personality and mood changes, and cognitive deficits, as well as cortical symptoms such as aphasia or amnesia. However, the development of deficits in vascular dementia usually occurs in a stepwise manner, while this patient's deficits developed in a short time period.

D) INCORRECT:

The hallmarks of frontotemporal dementia (FTD) are early, progressive aphasia or behavior and personality changes (e.g., disinhibition, apathy, hyperorality, and compulsive behaviors), which occur alongside degeneration of the frontal and/or temporal lobes. While this patient's performance on the five-minute recall test should raise suspicion for dementia, the lack of language dysfunction or personality changes and the presence of gait abnormalities make FTD an unlikely diagnosis in this case.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view)

There is atrophy of the left frontal (FL) and temporal lobe (TL) with prominence of the cerebrospinal fluid spaces (green overlay).

As the name suggests, frontotemporal dementia predominantly affects the frontal and temporal lobes. The specific pattern of brain atrophy varies by subtype. Although cerebral atrophy is often bilateral in frontotemporal dementia, it can be asymmetrical, as demonstrated in this example.

Because the majority of people develop some degree of brain atrophy as a part of normal aging, correlation with the clinical history is essential for this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

Lewy body dementia is characterized by early impairment in attention and executive function, with memory impairment developing later in the disease course. Diagnosis requires two of the following: cognitive fluctuations, visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism. While this patient demonstrates cognitive impairment, he does not have any hallucinations or features of parkinsonism, e.g., tremor or rigidity.
Image Description:

Microscopy of the substantia nigra of a patient with Parkinson disease (upper row: 60x magnification, lower row: 20x magnification; staining with antibodies against alpha-synuclein, counterstaining with Mayer hematoxylin)

Both Lewy bodies (spherical intracytoplasmic aggregates of alpha-synuclein; green overlay) and the strand-like Lewy neurites (neurites containing alpha-synuclein aggregates; white arrows) are visible.

F) INCORRECT:

Vitamin B12 deficiency develops after years of inadequate intake, malabsorption, or increased demand. The condition can manifest with symptoms such as memory impairment, personality changes, and paresthesias, which could lead to gait abnormalities. However, vitamin B12 deficiency typically results in loss of distal vibratory sense in the extremities (lower > upper), which is not present in this patient. Furthermore, urinary urgency would not be explained by B12 deficiency.
questions.hint: This patient's confusion, ataxic gait, and urinary symptoms suggest a cause of reversible dementia in older adults.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his parents several weeks after the family immigrated from Russia. The parents are worried because the child appears to have trouble seeing and has not started walking. The child was born at home and has never been evaluated by a physician. During the pregnancy, the mother had a week of fever, myalgia, diffuse rash, and bilateral nontender cervical adenopathy after the family adopted a cat. The patient is lethargic and irritable when aroused. Vital signs are within normal limits. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Ophthalmologic examination shows inflammation of the choroid and the retina in both eyes. An MRI of the head is shown. Which of the following additional findings is most likely in this patient?

choices.text: Maculopapular rash on palms and soles
Tuft of hair over the lumbosacral area
Loss of pain sensation in the cervicothoracic dermatomes

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A continuous machinery murmur arises from a patent ductus arteriosus (PDA). PDA is associated with congenital rubella infection but is not seen in congenital toxoplasmosis infection. While congenital rubella can also cause vision abnormalities (e.g., due to cataracts), it is not usually associated with hydrocephalus.

B) INCORRECT:

A maculopapular rash on the palms and soles is characteristic of congenital syphilis, which should be considered in children born to mothers who did not receive prenatal care. Congenital syphilis can manifest with hydrocephalus, but this child does not present with other findings consistent with this condition (e.g., hepatomegaly and jaundice, Hutchinson teeth, mulberry molars, facial or skeletal alterations, generalized lymphadenopathy). In addition, this patient's mother does not have a history compatible with syphilis.

C) CORRECT:

Signs of upper motor neuron damage (e.g., spasticity, hyperreflexia) are common in advanced, chronic hydrocephalus due to stretching of the motor cortices and pyramidal tracts around the dilated ventricles. The lower extremities are typically affected because the cortical regions responsible for processing the motor functions of the lower extremities are located in the medial precentral gyrus (according to the motor homunculus), which is the most stretched part of the primary motor cortex in patients with hydrocephalus. Other symptoms of hydrocephalus in children include difficulty feeding, irritability, and macrocephaly.

Another classic finding in congenital toxoplasmosis is diffuse intracranial calcifications. Pregnant women should avoid raw meats and contact with cat litter to prevent toxoplasmosis.

D) INCORRECT:

A tuft of hair in the lumbosacral region is associated with spina bifida occulta. More severe forms of spina bifida can be associated with myelomeningocele, which itself is associated with hydrocephalus. However, patients with myelomeningoceles have a gross deformity of the lumbosacral area, not relatively minor findings such as a tuft of hair. Spina bifida occulta is not usually associated with hydrocephalus.

E) INCORRECT:

Loss of pain sensation in the cervicothoracic dermatomes (i.e., in a shawl distribution) is consistent with syringomyelia. The development of a syrinx in the center of the cervical spinal cord progressively compresses neurons of the spinothalamic tract, which explains the loss of pain (and typically temperature) sensation in the upper extremities. Later findings can include weakness or even paralysis as alpha motor neurons become compromised. Hydrocephalus is not associated with this finding.
questions.hint: This patient likely developed congenital toxoplasmosis after his mother had a primary infection (fever, myalgia, and nontender cervical adenopathy following exposure to an infected cat). Cardinal manifestations of congenital toxoplasmosis include chorioretinitis and hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man is brought to the physician by his wife for progressively worsening confusion and forgetfulness. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows a flat affect and impaired short-term memory. An MRI of the brain is shown. Further evaluation of this patient is most likely to show which of the following findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Startle myoclonus is seen in many neurological and psychiatric syndromes. When occurring in combination with signs of rapidly progressing dementia (rapidly worsening confusion and memory loss), Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease should be considered. However, MRI of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease would show T2 signal amplification in the caudate nucleus rather than the ventriculomegaly seen here.
Image Description:

MRI head (left: T2-weighted image, axial plane; right: diffusion-weighted image (DWI), axial plane) of a patient with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD)

The DWI shows hyperintensities (examples indicated by arrows) in the putamen (red overlay), thalamus (yellow overlay), and caudate nucleus (green overlay), common locations for deep gray matter involvement with Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease. Sporadic CJD may also demonstrate ribbon-like signal hyperintensity of cerebral cortical gyri (cortical ribboning; not shown). A probable diagnosis of CJD can be made when expected MR imaging patterns are seen and CJD-mimicking disorders are confidently ruled out clinically.

B) INCORRECT:

Papilledema can be due to either communicating hydrocephalus or noncommunicating hydrocephalus. While this patient does show signs of impaired consciousness (increasing confusion and forgetfulness), he lacks characteristic signs of elevated ICP (e.g., nausea, vomiting, headaches, Cushing triad), making papilledema unlikely. NPH, which this patient most likely has, is only characterized by a mild and intermittent elevation in ICP, and papilledema would not be expected.

C) CORRECT:

A broad-based gait is a clumsy, irregular pattern of walk in which small steps are taken and the legs are spread wide. Gait dysfunction, dementia, and urinary incontinence make up the pathognomonic triad (“wet”, “wacky”, “wobbly”) of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

D) INCORRECT:

Postural instability is one of the cardinal signs of Parkinson disease. Patients with the disease can present with cognitive dysfunctions and dementia, similar to what is seen in this patient, but only later in the course of the disease. Parkinson disease is not associated with ventriculomegaly, which is seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Pill-rolling tremors are characteristic of Parkinson disease. Patients with the disease can manifest with cognitive dysfunctions and dementia, similar to what is seen in this patient, but only later in the course of the disease. Parkinson disease is not associated with the ventriculomegaly seen here.

Imaging is not routinely required for the diagnosis of Parkinson disease. It is reserved for atypical presentations to rule out other underlying disorders.

F) INCORRECT:

Choreiform movements are typically seen in Huntington disease. Huntington disease is associated with progressive cognitive deficits in advanced stages of the disease. MRI would show brain atrophy, particularly of the caudate nucleus, rather than the ventriculomegaly seen here.
questions.hint: In conjunction with the MRI findings (marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles without proportional sulcal enlargement), this patient's progressively worsening confusion and memory suggest normal pressure hydrocephalus, a condition that is most commonly seen in adults over the age of 60.

questions.text: A 73-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter for evaluation of increasing forgetfulness during the past 6 months. The daughter reports that he recently got lost while walking home from the grocery store. He has also been more irritable recently. On mental status examination, he has a normal affect. He is oriented to person and place but cannot recall which month it is. He recalls memories from more than 20 years ago in great detail but cannot state his home address or the name of his recently born grandson. His gait is normal and there is no nystagmus. An MRI of the brain is shown. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of the radiologic findings?

choices.text: Obstruction of the foramen of Monro

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Inflammation of the choroid plexus (choroid plexitis), which is most commonly caused by CNS infection (e.g., tuberculosis, cryptococcosis) can result in increased CSF production and thereby cause lateral ventricle enlargement, as seen here on the T2 weighted MRI. However, this patient does not have any clinical features of CNS infection (e.g., fever, headache, meningism) and there is no enlargement of the choroid plexus in the lateral ventricles on imaging to suggest choroid plexitis.

B) CORRECT:

Atrophy of the cortex of the brain (especially the medial temporal lobe structures) with narrowing of the gyri and widening of the sulci are characteristic neuroradiological findings in patients with Alzheimer disease. The ventricular dilation seen on imaging is a consequence of cerebral loss, with the ventricles expanding to fill the volume formerly occupied by the cortex. This phenomenon is known as hydrocephalus ex vacuo but unlike true hydrocephalus, there is no primary pathology of cerebrospinal fluid production or outflow in patients with Alzheimer disease. This patient's normal gait and lack of urinary symptoms are important in differentiating this presentation of Alzheimer disease from the classic presentation of hydrocephalus, given that the neuroimaging findings in both conditions are similar.

C) INCORRECT:

Demyelination of periventricular areas is seen in multiple sclerosis and Wernicke encephalopathy. Patients affected by either of these conditions can develop irreversible memory loss and personality changes, as seen here. However, the onset of memory loss and personality changes would be preceded by a history of fatigue and episodic neurological deficits in the case of multiple sclerosis, and the triad of confusion, ataxia, and ophthalmoplegia (due to mamillary body atrophy) in the case of Wernicke encephalopathy. Furthermore, the T2 weighted MRI of this patient does not show any evidence of periventricular demyelination.

D) INCORRECT:

Bleeding into the ventricular system can cause obstructive hydrocephalus and thereby result in ventricular enlargement, as seen here in the T2 weighted MRI. However, intraventricular hemorrhage usually manifests acutely with a severe headache and features of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., nausea, vomiting, blurred vision), unlike this patient who presents with cognitive impairment and mood changes that have progressively worsened over the past 6 months. Furthermore, there is no radiological evidence of an intraventricular hemorrhage on this patient's MRI (e.g., mixed fluid attenuation)

E) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of the foramen of Monro, which is typically caused by a tumor (e.g., colloid cyst), would result in unilateral (asymmetrical) lateral ventricle enlargement, unlike this patient who has symmetrical enlargement of both the lateral ventricles on the T2 weighted MRI.
questions.hint: This elderly patient has progressively worsening memory loss (especially of recently formed memories), mood alterations, and disorientation, which are all suggestive of dementia. Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia in individuals aged > 65 years.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of headaches for the past 2 weeks. His headaches tend to occur in the morning and are associated with nausea and vomiting. One month ago, the patient was admitted to the hospital because of fever, irritability, and neck rigidity, and he was successfully treated with antibiotics. His temperature today is 37.5°C (98.5°F). An MRI of the brain shows bilateral ventricular enlargement and enlargement of the subarachnoid space. Which of the following is the most likely explanation of the patient's condition?

choices.text: Increased CSF production by the choroid plexus
Impaired CSF flow through the arachnoid granulations
Impaired CSF drainage into the subarachnoid space
Impaired CSF drainage into the fourth ventricle

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased CSF production by the choroid plexus is seen in choroid plexus papilloma, a rare benign pediatric tumor that can manifest with features of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., headache, nausea, vomiting) as well as enlargement of both the ventricular and subarachnoid spaces (communicating hydrocephalus). However, a history of fever and neck rigidity would not be expected with a choroid plexus papilloma, and the MRI would also show a well-defined, intraventricular, lobulated mass that enhances brilliantly because of its high vascularization.

B) CORRECT:

CSF drains from the 4th ventricle into the subarachnoid space and from the subarachnoid space into dural venous sinuses via arachnoid granulations. The blockage of arachnoid granulations by degenerating neutrophils and proliferating fibroblasts (i.e., arachnoid scarring) is a complication of bacterial meningitis. This blockage results in the accumulation of CSF in the subarachnoid space and the ventricular spaces, the subsequent symmetric enlargement of the entire ventricular system (communicating hydrocephalus), and features of raised intracranial pressure (e.g., early-morning headaches, nausea, vomiting). Communicating hydrocephalus can also be a complication of subarachnoid hemorrhage.
Image Description:

From the outside in:
1. Scalp
2. Periosteum
3. Skull
4. Dura mater
5. Arachnoid mater
6. Pia mater

Diploic veins lie within the inner and outer tables of the skull. Dural venous sinuses lie between the inner and outer layers of the dura mater and are connected to the extracranial veins by emissary veins. Falx cerebri (as well as the falx cerebelli and tentorium cerebelli not shown in this image) are extensions of the dura mater. Arachnoid trabeculae are strands of delicate connective tissue that extend between the arachnoid and pia mater. Arachnoid granulations (villi) are finger-like projections of the arachnoid mater that invaginate into the dural venous sinuses.

C) INCORRECT:

Drainage of CSF into the subarachnoid space would be impaired upon blockage of the median foramen of Magendie or the lateral foramina of Luschka, which connect the 4th ventricle with the subarachnoid space. This blockage can occur as a complication of bacterial meningitis and lead to bilateral ventricular enlargement, as seen here. However, obstructive hydrocephalus only causes dilation of the ventricles upstream of the obstruction, which is why the subarachnoid space would not be enlarged in this case. Enlargement of the subarachnoid space in this patient suggests a different pathological process.
Image Description:

Within the brain, there are several interconnected CSF-filled spaces (ventricles). The largest of these are the lateral ventricles (first and second ventricles), which are located within the cerebral hemispheres. The third ventricle lies in the diencephalon, between the two thalamic hemispheres, and has several recesses. The fourth ventricle is located in the rhomboid fossa (dorsal to the pons/medulla oblongata). The lateral ventricles are connected to the third ventricle via the interventricular foramina. The third ventricle is connected to the fourth ventricle by the cerebral aqueduct. The fourth ventricle also connects the ventricular system to the subarachnoid space (which is also filled with CSF) via several openings (e.g., the median aperture).

D) INCORRECT:

Impaired CSF drainage from the 3rd ventricle into the 4th ventricle is caused by obstruction of the cerebral aqueduct, which can occur as a complication of bacterial meningitis and lead to bilateral ventricular enlargement, as seen here. However, obstructive hydrocephalus only causes dilation of the ventricles upstream of the obstruction, so the subarachnoid space would not be enlarged due to aqueductal stenosis. Enlargement of the subarachnoid space in this patient suggests a different pathological process.
Image Description:

Cranial CT (axial view) of a 13-year-old boy

A large, liquor-like, hypodense lesion (red area) is located in the posterior cranial fossa in images 1–3. This lesion is most likely an arachnoid cyst compressing the cerebral aqueduct (A), which prevents the free circulation of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) from the ventricles to the subarachnoid space. As a result, the third ventricle (III) and the lateral ventricles (hatched area) are dilated, and there is transependymal egress of CSF (green shaded area, images 4 and 5).

C = cistern of great cerebral vein
T = inferior horn of the lateral ventricle

E) INCORRECT:

Compensatory enlargement of CSF spaces, which is seen in hydrocephalus ex vacuo, occurs secondary to loss of brain volume in neurodegenerative diseases or stroke. An MRI would show biventricular enlargement and enlargement of the subarachnoid space, as seen here. However, hydrocephalus ex vacuo does not cause any symptoms because it does not affect intracerebral pressure, and it is not typically seen in children.
questions.hint: The combination of fever, irritability, and neck rigidity is characteristic of meningitis. This patient's current symptoms and MRI findings indicate communicating hydrocephalus, which can be a complication of meningitis.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-year history of frequent falls. During this time, she reports “feeling insecure while walking” and “finding it hard to lift my feet off the ground.” She has hypertension treated with lisinopril. There is no family history of malignancy or neurological disease. She is oriented to person, place, and time. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 128/72 mm Hg. On neurologic examination, no sensory changes are present. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ in all extremities. She has a broad-based gait; when asked to turn 180 degrees, she has to take multiple small steps. MRI of the brain shows marked dilation of the lateral ventricles. There is mild narrowing of the sulci disproportionate to the degree of ventricular enlargement. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ventriculoperitoneal shunting is the definitive therapy for patients with normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH), which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient. However, NPH should be confirmed before treatment is started.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's frequent falls, magnetic gait, and ventriculomegaly on MRI suggest normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). Although this patient does not have the classic triad of symptoms, gait apraxia is the most relevant finding of NPH and should, therefore, raise clinical suspicion for this condition and warrant further evaluation. NPH is diagnosed based on typical clinical features, supportive findings on imaging (i.e., ventriculomegaly without or out of proportion to sulcal enlargement), and normal or only mildly elevated opening pressure. To evaluate opening pressure, a lumbar tap test should be performed in patients with suspected NPH. Normal or mildly elevated opening pressure and gait improvement following CSF removal (30–50 mL) strongly support the diagnosis. The latter can help predict response to cerebral shunt placement. CSF analysis can also be performed during this procedure to help rule out differential diagnoses.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial plane)

There is marked dilatation of the lateral ventricles (green overlay) with mild sulcal enlargement (red overlay). The findings are suggestive of normal pressure hydrocephalus as opposed to age-related or neurodegenerative cerebral atrophy.

Periventricular hypointensities (examples indicated by white arrowheads) are also seen and may reflect transependymal edema due to elevated cerebrospinal fluid pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

A levodopa challenge test is used to support the diagnosis of Parkinson disease (PD), which is characterized by postural instability with frequent falls and gait abnormalities with small steps. However, PD is characterized by a narrow-based shuffling gait, with episodes of freezing and/or propulsion; this patient's broad-based and unsteady gait is inconsistent with a parkinsonian gait. In addition, she does not have any of the hallmark symptoms of PD, such as bradykinesia, resting tremor, and rigidity, and her MRI shows ventriculomegaly, which is not expected in PD.

D) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is the first-line treatment for idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), which does not cause gait abnormalities but manifests with headaches and visual disturbances. In addition, brain imaging would be normal in IIH. Furthermore, this patient does not have any risk factors for IIH (e.g., obesity, childbearing age, use of retinoids or tetracyclines). This patient most likely has normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). There is some evidence of an association between acetazolamide and clinical improvement in NPH but the drug is not yet recommended for the treatment of this condition.

E) INCORRECT:

A Schilling test can be used to determine the cause of vitamin B12 deficiency, which can result in subacute combined degeneration (SCD) of the spinal cord and cause gait abnormalities (sensory ataxia). However, vitamin B12 deficiency is also associated with peripheral neuropathy, paresthesias, and spastic paresis, none of which are seen in this patient. In addition, vitamin B12 deficiency does not cause abnormalities on brain imaging, and the Schilling test is no longer routinely used in clinical practice.
questions.hint: This patient's condition often manifests with the classic 3 Ws, Wet (urinary incontinence), Wacky (dementia), and Wobbly (gait apraxia), although some patients may present with only some of these features.

questions.text:
A 75-year-old woman with well-controlled type 2 diabetes reports that she fell twice during the past 3 months but did not sustain any significant injury. She reports instability while standing, difficulty getting out of a car, trouble initiating gait, and a tendency to tip over while making sharp turns.
Her husband has noticed some impairment in her short-term memory, but she has no functional impairments and is independent in her activities of daily living. She also reports urinary urgency and the need to wake up two or three times a night to pass urine, although she is not incontinent. She has no pain in her back, hips, or knees.
Her vital signs are normal, and she does not have orthostasis. Her vision, hearing, peripheral circulation, and joint examinations are normal. Her Folstein Mini-Mental Status Examination score is 26 out of 30. Her neurologic examination reveals normal extraocular movements, as well as normal axial and appendicular tone with intact power and coordination. She has diminished pinprick and temperature sensation in her feet, but her large-fiber modalities (vibration and position sense) and deep-tendon reflexes are normal. Her gait is wide-based, she takes short steps, and she has a tendency to drag both feet.
Her most recent glycated hemoglobin measurement was 6.7% (reference range, 4.3–5.6). An MRI of the brain is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parkinson-plus syndromes, such as progressive supranuclear palsy, can occasionally manifest predominantly with gait dysfunction accompanied by mild cognitive impairment and urinary symptoms. However, the absence of extrapyramidal findings on neurologic examination, a lack of abnormalities in extraocular eye movements, the absence of orthostasis, and normal coordination examination make those diagnoses less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Although autonomic neuropathy may be associated with urinary symptoms, it is most typically associated with gastroparesis and postural hypotension, not with cognitive impairment.

C) INCORRECT:

Parkinson-plus syndromes, such as multiple-system atrophy, can occasionally manifest predominantly with gait dysfunction accompanied by mild cognitive impairment and urinary symptoms. However, the absence of extrapyramidal findings on neurologic examination, a lack of abnormalities in extraocular eye movements, the absence of orthostasis, and normal coordination examination make those diagnoses less likely.

D) CORRECT:

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) is typically characterized by a triad of gait impairment, cognitive impairment, and urinary dysfunction. Not all patients with NPH have the textbook “gait apraxia,” and the triad is neither necessary nor sufficient to consider the diagnosis. NPH is potentially reversible if detected early and if the right candidates are selected for shunt surgery. Positive response to supplementary tests — such as a large-volume lumbar puncture, extended cerebrospinal fluid diversion by a lumbar spinal catheter, or cerebrospinal fluid outflow resistance tests — increases the likelihood of a response to shunt surgery.

Many other disorders in older adults that manifest with similar symptoms and signs can often be excluded with careful neurologic examination and imaging. The most common disorder that mimics NPH is vascular dementia. However, this patient has no clinical history of a stroke, and the MRI scan does not reveal large-vessel infarcts or subcortical ischemic changes that would suggest a vascular etiology. The scan reveals dilation of the ventricular system, including the third and fourth ventricles. NPH is characterized by enlarged ventricles on imaging, with normal opening pressure on lumbar puncture.

Key learning point: The triad of gait impairment, cognitive impairment, and urinary dysfunction is most consistent with a diagnosis of normal-pressure hydrocephalus.

E) INCORRECT:

The most common disorder that mimics normal-pressure hydrocephalus is vascular dementia. However, this patient has no clinical history of a stroke, and the MRI scan does not reveal large-vessel infarcts or subcortical ischemic changes that would suggest a vascular etiology.

questions.text:
A 70-year-old woman reports a 9-month history of difficulty with her gait and balance as well as progressive cognitive decline. She has had two falls, has difficulty walking on uneven surfaces, has a tendency to shuffle, and has trouble getting in and out of chairs. More recently, in the past 3 months, she has also noticed some difficulty with her short-term memory and urinary urgency, along with occasional incontinence that she had not experienced before.
Her vital signs and physical examination are normal. Her gait is wide-based, and her feet point outward; she takes short steps and has a tendency to drag both feet. Her Folstein Mini-Mental Status Examination score is 22 out of 30. Her eye movements are normal. She has no resting or action tremor, and her tone, motor strength, reflexes, position sense, and vibration sense are normal.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients who have dementia with Lewy bodies usually present with fluctuations in sensorium, visual hallucinations, and cognitive impairment along with features of parkinsonism.

B) CORRECT:

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) classically manifests with abnormal gait, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment. The gait is bradykinetic, broad-based, magnetic, and shuffling. Urinary symptoms include increased frequency, urgency, or frank incontinence. Cognitive impairment can manifest with memory problems, psychomotor slowing, and executive dysfunction. Although this triad is suggestive of NPH, recent studies have shown it is neither necessary nor sufficient for the diagnosis of NPH. Supplemental testing with a large-volume lumbar puncture, an extended cerebrospinal-fluid drainage trial, or measurement of resistance to cerebrospinal fluid outflow is essential to select the correct patients for shunt surgery.

Key learning point: The diagnosis suggested by the findings of abnormal gait, urinary incontinence, and cognitive impairment with predominant and early onset of gait dysfunction is normal-pressure hydrocephalus.

C) INCORRECT:

Multiple-system atrophy can cause gait abnormalities and urinary incontinence similar to NPH, but patients typically have autonomic findings (orthostatic hypotension) and extrapyramidal or cerebellar dysfunction.

D) INCORRECT:

Although patients with Parkinson disease can present with predominant gait symptoms, they frequently have bradykinesia, an asymmetric resting tremor, and rigidity.

E) INCORRECT:

Common symptoms of progressive supranuclear palsy include axial rigidity and eye-movement abnormalities (especially limitations of vertical gaze).

questions.text:
A 5-month-old girl is brought in by her mother for evaluation of fussiness and a weight check. She was born at 26 weeks’ gestation and was discharged from the neonatal intensive care unit 5 weeks ago. She established care at that time and has had a visiting nurse checking her weight weekly. She was initially gaining weight well, but in the past week, she has become increasingly fussy and has had decreased feedings.
On physical examination, her vital signs are within normal limits. Her weight and length are at the 30th percentile on a prematurity-adjusted growth chart. Her head circumference is at the 97th percentile. Her growth chart since birth is obtained (figure).
Which one of the following factors is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anoxic brain injury would not be expected to contribute to hydrocephalus.

B) INCORRECT:

Retinopathy of prematurity would be seen on funduscopic examination and can cause eye pathology such as cataracts, but it is not a known cause of hydrocephalus.

C) INCORRECT:

Maternal use of prenatal glucocorticoids has been shown to reduce, rather than increase, the risk of IVH and subsequent hydrocephalus.

D) CORRECT:

The combination of increased head circumference, irritability, and poor eating in a premature infant is consistent with hydrocephalus. Physical examination would also demonstrate a bulging anterior fontanelle. With more significant hydrocephalus, cranial nerve palsies may also be seen.

Intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH) is an important cause of hydrocephalus. The hemorrhage prompts an inflammatory response that leads to fibrosis, impairing absorption of the cerebrospinal fluid. IVH can cause either transient or permanent hydrocephalus, and the process can occur slowly or rapidly. The risk of developing posthemorrhagic hydrocephalus has been shown to increase with the severity of IVH: 1% risk for grade 1 IVH, 4% for grade 2, 25% for grade 3, and 28% for grade 4. IVH is commonly seen in infants less than 30 weeks of age, so clinicians should evaluate head circumference closely in premature infants, using appropriate growth curves.

Other causes of hydrocephalus include central nervous system (CNS) malformations (such as Chiari malformations, Dandy-Walker malformation, spina bifida, and myelomeningocele), congenital infections, CNS infections (such as bacterial meningitis), genetic defects, trauma, teratogens, and tumors.

Key learning point: In premature infants, intraventricular hemorrhages increase the risk for hydrocephalus.

E) INCORRECT:

Congenital infection with cytomegalovirus can be associated with microcephaly but does not cause hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 77-year-old woman is brought to the office for gradually increasing confusion and difficulty walking for the past 4 months. Her daughter is concerned because she has been forgetful and seems to be walking more slowly. She has also had increasingly frequent episodes of urinary incontinence and now wears an adult diaper daily. She is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. She has a broad-based gait and takes short steps. Sensation is intact and muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy-bodies (DLB) is characterized by early impairments in attention and executive function, with memory impairment developing later in the disease course. In addition, diagnosis requires two of the following: cognitive fluctuations (episodes of worse cognition and alertness interspersed with periods of relatively normal function), visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism. While this patient demonstrates cognitive impairment and a slow gait with short steps, she does not have any other features of parkinsonism, e.g., tremor or rigidity. Also, the patient lacks visual hallucinations or cognitive fluctuations.

B) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia, with increasing prevalence after 60 years of age. Memory impairment is the cardinal and most common initial symptom, while behavioral symptoms, primitive reflexes, and urinary incontinence may present late in the disease course. The early development of urinary incontinence and gait disturbances in this patient is not typical of Alzheimer disease.

C) CORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) manifests with gait instability, cognitive disturbance, and urinary incontinence – the classic “wet, wacky, and wobbly” triad. Gait changes are typically symmetrical, while cognitive impairment primarily manifests as decreased attention span and concentration, without psychotic features that may be characteristic of other causes of dementia. (See table “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia”).
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

D) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for vascular dementia include hypertension and dyslipidemia. Its clinical presentation is highly variable as different regions of the brain may be involved in the vascular insults that lead to cognitive deterioration. Symptoms can include gait disturbances, urinary frequency, personality and mood changes, and cognitive deficits, as well as cortical symptoms such as aphasia or amnesia. However, vascular dementia is associated clinically with the development of deficits in a stepwise manner, and not gradual development as in this patient. Moreover, exacerbations associated with vascular events may be clinically apparent, e.g., as unprovoked falls in the patient's history, or as signs of stroke on examination.

E) INCORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is characterized by progressive dementia and visual/cerebellar disturbances, which could be consistent with this patient's gait instability and memory impairment. However, CJD typically progresses very rapidly and is associated with additional symptoms of myoclonus (present in > 90% of patients), pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction, and akinetic mutism, all of which are absent in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient's confusion, gait apraxia, and urinary incontinence constitute the classic triad of a condition associated with reversible dementia in older adults.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the office by his parents for the evaluation of progressive enlargement of his head circumference. He was born at term and has met all developmental milestones. The patient is at the 50th percentile for length, 50th percentile for weight, and 95th percentile for head circumference. He appears well-nourished. He is afebrile. Physical examination shows a tense anterior fontanelle. The eyes deviate inferiorly and the eyelids are retracted. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diuretics such as furosemide decrease CSF production and are sometimes used as temporary therapy in patients too unstable to undergo surgery. However, a different diagnostic study is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Although serial lumbar punctures were used in the past as a temporary measure in preterm infants with posthemorrhagic hydrocephalus as a complication of intraventricular hemorrhage, the procedure is no longer recommended. A different diagnostic study is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

C) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide may decrease CSF production and is sometimes used as temporary therapy in patients too unstable to undergo surgery. However, a different diagnostic study is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

D) INCORRECT:

CSF shunts are a definitive treatment for hydrocephalus. However, before proceeding with a surgical intervention, a different diagnostic study is required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

E) CORRECT:

A patient with hydrocephalus requires neuroimaging to determine the extent of the condition and the underlying cause. Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality in newborns and young infants in whom the anterior fontanelle is still open because it allows direct visualization of the brain. Moreover, ultrasound does not involve radiation and does not require sedation of the patient.

Although standard MRI is safe for infants, sedation is required, making it less appropriate than ultrasonography. Ultra-fast MRI techniques, however, do not require infant sedation and can be used as an alternative to ultrasonography. MRI is the preferred imaging modality in older children in whom the anterior fontanelle has closed (it usually closes at 12–18 months of age).
questions.hint: This patient presents with macrocephaly, tense fontanelle, and a sunset eye sign, all of which suggest hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man is brought to the office by his wife because of difficulties walking for the past year. He has had multiple falls over the past 4 months. Over the past 6 months, he has had progressive urinary urgency and now wears an adult diaper because he is not always able to control the urge to void. He used to drive, but his wife convinced him to stop after she noticed that he was becoming increasingly inattentive while driving. Examination shows a broad-based gait with slow and short steps. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. On mental status examination, he is oriented to person and place but not to time. Attention and concentration are impaired. He recalls only one of three objects after 5 minutes. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

The symptoms of NPH likely result from stretching of white matter tracts due to an increase in cerebrospinal fluid volume. Patients suspected of having NPH should undergo MRI to identify ventriculomegaly. The diagnosis is confirmed by symptomatic improvement following lumbar punctures to remove CSF (lumbar tap test). If lumbar puncture is effective, placement of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt is the definitive therapy.
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

B) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is used for the treatment of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH). Acetazolamide reduces cerebrospinal fluid production and flow from the choroid plexus, which in turn can lower intracranial pressure. However, it is unlikely that this patient has IIH, as this disease typically affects women aged 15– 44 years and manifests with headaches and visual changes. There is some evidence of an association between acetazolamide and clinical improvement in patients with NPH. However, the drug is not yet recommended for the treatment of this condition, except in patients who do not respond to first-line therapy.

C) INCORRECT:

Donepezil is used for symptomatic management of Alzheimer disease. Although this patient has some cognitive deficits that also appear in Alzheimer disease (e.g., memory loss, impaired attention), the presence of urinary incontinence and gait instability make NPH more likely. Donepezil therapy has no role in the management of NPH.

D) INCORRECT:

Cervical decompression and fusion are the surgical management of cervical myelopathy. Although cervical myelopathy can result in upper motor neuron weakness (3+ reflexes, flexor plantar reflex) of the lower extremity, which may result in gait instability, it does not cause cognitive impairment. Cognitive impairments indicate his lesion is cortical in origin rather than from the spinal cord. Cervical decompression and fusion have no role in the management of NPH.

E) INCORRECT:

Sertraline can be used for the treatment of pseudodementia by treating the underlying depression. Although this patient has cognitive decline, he lacks mood symptoms (e.g., sadness, anhedonia) of depression. Additionally, his incontinence and gait instability make NPH the most likely explanation for his cognitive impairment; sertraline has no role in the management of NPH.
questions.hint: The presence of a broad-based gait, difficulty in attention and concentration, short-term memory deficits, and urinary incontinence in an older individual are consistent with normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH).

questions.text:
An 80-year-old man is brought to the clinic by his family with a 6-month history of unsteady gait and progressive difficulty initiating walking. He has occasional urinary incontinence and mild forgetfulness but continues to recognize family. Neurologic examination reveals a broad-based gait with short, shuffling steps. Strength in his upper and lower extremities is normal, and there is no resting tremor. He has not improved with medications for suspected Parkinson disease (see lab result and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Cerebrospinal fluid




 Pressure
220 mm H₂0
200 - 250 mm H₂0



Brain MRI: Enlarged ventricles out of proportion to cortical atrophy
Which of the following diagnoses best explains his condition?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Parkinson disease typically presents with resting tremor, rigidity, and bradykinesia, along with a positive response to dopaminergic medications. The absence of these features, along with the presence of urinary incontinence and cognitive decline, and the MRI findings of ventriculomegaly, do not align with Parkinson disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Vascular dementia often presents with a stepwise cognitive decline and is associated with cerebrovascular events. Neuroimaging typically shows multiple infarcts or white matter changes. The progressive gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and MRI findings of ventriculomegaly without infarcts do not support vascular dementia.

C) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease usually presents with early memory decline and diffuse cortical atrophy, particularly in the medial temporal lobes. The prominent gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and MRI findings of ventricular enlargement without significant cortical atrophy are not typical of Alzheimer disease.

D) CORRECT:

Normal-pressure hydrocephalus manifests with a triad of gait disturbance, mild cognitive changes, and urinary incontinence. The patient's broad-based, shuffling gait indicates frontal-subcortical circuit impairment. Cognitive deficits, with preserved recognition, suggest mild dementia due to periventricular white matter tract involvement. MRI findings of ventriculomegaly disproportionate to cortical atrophy indicate cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) dynamic disturbance. Normal CSF pressure supports impaired CSF resorption without increased intracranial pressure. The pathophysiology involves inadequate CSF reabsorption by arachnoid granulations, leading to ventricular enlargement and neural pathway disruption.

Key learning point: Normal-pressure hydrocephalus is characterized by the triad of gait disturbance, urinary incontinence, and cognitive dysfunction, along with dilated ventricles on imaging.

questions.text: You are seeing a 77-year-old woman who is brought to your clinic due to gradually increasing confusion and difficulty walking over the past 4 months. Her daughter reports that she has become more forgetful and her walking has slowed. She has also developed more frequent episodes of urinary incontinence and now wears an adult diaper daily. On examination, she is confused and oriented only to person and place. She recalls 2 out of 3 words immediately and 1 out of 3 after five minutes. Her gait is broad-based with short steps.
