Sensation is intact and muscle strength is 5/5 throughout. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease (CJD) is characterized by progressive dementia and visual/cerebellar disturbances, which could be consistent with this patient's gait instability and memory impairment. However, CJD typically progresses very rapidly and is associated with additional symptoms of myoclonus (present in > 90% of patients), pyramidal/extrapyramidal dysfunction, and akinetic mutism, all of which are absent in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Dementia with Lewy-bodies (DLB) is characterized by early impairments in attention and executive function, with memory impairment developing later in the disease course. In addition, diagnosis requires two of the following: cognitive fluctuations (episodes of worse cognition and alertness interspersed with periods of relatively normal function), visual hallucinations, and parkinsonism. While this patient demonstrates cognitive impairment and a slow gait with short steps, she does not have any other features of parkinsonism, e.g., tremor or rigidity. Also, the patient lacks visual hallucinations or cognitive fluctuations.

C) INCORRECT:

Alzheimer disease is the most common cause of dementia, with increasing prevalence after 60 years of age. Memory impairment is the cardinal and most common initial symptom, while behavioral symptoms, primitive reflexes, and urinary incontinence may present late in the disease course. The early development of urinary incontinence and gait disturbances in this patient is not typical of Alzheimer disease.

D) CORRECT:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH) manifests with gait instability, cognitive disturbance, and urinary incontinence – the classic “wet, wacky, and wobbly” triad. Gait changes are typically symmetrical, while cognitive impairment primarily manifests as decreased attention span and concentration, without psychotic features that may be characteristic of other causes of dementia. (See table “Differential diagnosis of subtypes of dementia”).

Key learning point: Normal pressure hydrocephalus presents with the triad of gait disturbance, cognitive impairment, and urinary incontinence—often remembered as "wet, wacky, and wobbly."
Image Description:

Normal pressure hydrocephalus is a form of chronic communicating hydrocephalus that primarily affects older individuals (> 60 years of age). It is characterized by a triad of clinical features (urinary incontinence, dementia, and apraxic/magnetic gait) with normal or only episodically increased intracranial pressure. Definitive treatment involves drainage of excess CSF via a cerebral shunt, usually into the peritoneum (ventriculoperitoneal shunt).

E) INCORRECT:

Risk factors for vascular dementia include hypertension and dyslipidemia. Its clinical presentation is highly variable as different regions of the brain may be involved in the vascular insults that lead to cognitive deterioration. Symptoms can include gait disturbances, urinary frequency, personality and mood changes, and cognitive deficits, as well as cortical symptoms such as aphasia or amnesia. However, vascular dementia is associated clinically with the development of deficits in a stepwise manner, and not gradual development as in this patient. Moreover, exacerbations associated with vascular events may be clinically apparent, e.g., as unprovoked falls in the patient's history, or as signs of stroke on examination.
questions.hint: This patient's confusion, gait apraxia, and urinary incontinence constitute the classic triad of a condition associated with reversible dementia in older adults.

questions.text: You are seeing a 5-month-old male infant brought to your clinic by his parents because of progressive enlargement of his head circumference. He was born at term and has met all developmental milestones. His length and weight are at the 50th percentile, and his head circumference is at the 95th percentile. He is afebrile. On examination, he has a tense anterior fontanelle, with downward deviation of the eyes and retracted eyelids. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Diuretics such as furosemide decrease CSF production and are sometimes used as temporary therapy in patients too unstable to undergo surgery. However, a different diagnostic study is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide may decrease CSF production and is sometimes used as temporary therapy in patients too unstable to undergo surgery. However, a different diagnostic study is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

C) INCORRECT:

CSF shunts are a definitive treatment for hydrocephalus. However, before proceeding with a surgical intervention, a different diagnostic study is required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.

D) CORRECT:

A patient with hydrocephalus requires neuroimaging to determine the extent of the condition and the underlying cause. Ultrasound is the preferred imaging modality in newborns and young infants in whom the anterior fontanelle is still open because it allows direct visualization of the brain. Moreover, ultrasound does not involve radiation and does not require sedation of the patient.

Although standard MRI is safe for infants, sedation is required, making it less appropriate than ultrasonography. Ultra-fast MRI techniques, however, do not require infant sedation and can be used as an alternative to ultrasonography. MRI is the preferred imaging modality in older children in whom the anterior fontanelle has closed (it usually closes at 12–18 months of age).

Key learning point: Cranial ultrasonography is the preferred initial imaging modality for evaluating hydrocephalus in infants with an open anterior fontanelle.

E) INCORRECT:

Although serial lumbar punctures were used in the past as a temporary measure in preterm infants with posthemorrhagic hydrocephalus as a complication of intraventricular hemorrhage, the procedure is no longer recommended. A different diagnostic study is first required to confirm the diagnosis and determine the underlying cause.
questions.hint: This patient presents with macrocephaly, tense fontanelle, and a sunset eye sign, all of which suggest hydrocephalus.

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presents with a 6-month history of progressive gait instability, urinary urgency, and memory difficulties. His wife reports that he has a broad-based shuffling gait and frequent falls. Vital signs are normal. CT head is shown. Lumbar puncture is performed with an opening pressure of 12 mm Hg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with the classic triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH): gait apraxia, dementia, and urinary incontinence with normal opening pressure. After checking opening pressure, the next step in the CSF tap test for suspected NPH is removal of 30–50 mL of CSF. The CSF tap test helps confirm the diagnosis and predicts the response to shunt placement by assessing gait improvement following CSF removal.

B) INCORRECT:

Acetazolamide is used to reduce CSF production in conditions with elevated intracranial pressure. This patient's normal opening pressure and clinical presentation are consistent with normal pressure hydrocephalus, which does not require medications to reduce intracranial pressure.

C) INCORRECT:

Serial lumbar punctures are used as temporizing measures in acute hydrocephalus with elevated intracranial pressure. As this patient has normal pressure hydrocephalus with normal opening pressure, serial drainage is unnecessary.

D) INCORRECT:

External ventricular drain placement is indicated for acute hydrocephalus with elevated intracranial pressure requiring urgent CSF diversion. As this patient has normal pressure hydrocephalus with normal opening pressure, emergency drainage is unnecessary.

E) INCORRECT:

Mannitol is an osmotic diuretic used to reduce elevated intracranial pressure in acute settings. As this patient has normal pressure hydrocephalus with normal opening pressure, osmotic therapy is inappropriate.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man presents with a 4-month history of progressive gait instability and recent episodes of urinary urgency. His wife reports that he has become increasingly apathetic and forgetful, often losing track of conversations. Physical examination reveals a broad-based, shuffling gait with short steps and mild cognitive impairment with poor attention span. The only finding on this patient's MRI brain is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Lumbar puncture with cerebrospinal fluid removal

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While this patient has urinary urgency, the combination of gait apraxia, dementia, and urinary symptoms is the classic triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH). This diagnosis is further supported by ventriculomegaly without proportional sulcal enlargement on MRI, which suggests NPH rather than age-related cerebral atrophy. Urinary incontinence in NPH is neurogenic due to ventricular dilation affecting detrusor control fibers, not infectious. Although urinalysis can be obtained to rule out concomitant urinary tract infection, it would not confirm the most likely diagnosis or explain this patient's other neurological symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

A trial of carbidopa/levodopa is appropriate for suspected Parkinson disease, but this patient presents with the classic triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus: gait apraxia, dementia, and urinary incontinence. Additionally, broad-based gait apraxia is not consistent with Parkinson disease.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – This patient presents with the classic triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (NPH): gait apraxia, dementia, and urinary incontinence. MRI is typically preferred over CT head to evaluate NPH as it enables CSF flow assessment, although CT head can be used to rule out hydrocephalus in acute settings. This patient's MRI shows ventricular enlargement without proportional sulcal widening seen in age-related cerebral atrophy. A CSF tap test (lumbar puncture with removal of 30–50 mL of CSF) is the most appropriate next step. This test involves measuring opening pressure and assessing for gait improvement following CSF removal, which supports the diagnosis and can help predict the response to shunt placement.

D) INCORRECT:

While cognitive assessment may be part of a comprehensive evaluation, the combination of gait apraxia, urinary symptoms, and characteristic MRI findings (i.e., ventricular enlargement without proportional sulcal widening seen in age-related cerebral atrophy) strongly suggests normal pressure hydrocephalus. A more targeted diagnostic approach is indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with the classic triad of normal pressure hydrocephalus (gait apraxia, dementia, and urinary incontinence) and characteristic features of hydrocephalus on MRI (ventricular enlargement without proportional sulcal widening seen in age-related cerebral atrophy). Neurosurgical consultation would be premature without first confirming the diagnosis by checking the opening pressure and assessing the effect of CSF removal to predict the response to shunt placement.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with severe headache, nausea, and altered mental status that developed over 6 hours following a witnessed syncopal episode. Physical examination shows an abducens nerve palsy. CT head shows acute hydrocephalus with dilated third and lateral ventricles, but the fourth ventricle appears normal in size. No hemorrhage or tumor is visible. What is the most appropriate immediate intervention for this patient's condition?

choices.text: Urgent neurosurgical consultation for external ventricular drain placement
Lumbar puncture for opening pressure measurement and CSF analysis
Urgent MRI brain with gadolinium to identify obstructing lesion

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct – Severe headache, altered mental status, and abducens nerve palsy, combined with this patient's CT findings, are consistent with noncommunicating hydrocephalus with increased intracranial pressure. External ventricular drain placement is the appropriate temporizing measure for this condition. The CT findings indicate obstruction at or distal to the cerebral aqueduct, preventing CSF flow to the subarachnoid space. An external ventricular drain directly drains CSF from the obstructed ventricular system above the blockage, providing immediate intracranial pressure reduction.

B) INCORRECT:

Severe headache, altered mental status, and abducens nerve palsy, combined with this patient's CT findings, are consistent with noncommunicating hydrocephalus with increased intracranial pressure. Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in this condition due to the risk of brain herniation. The CT findings of dilated third and lateral ventricles with a normal fourth ventricle indicate an obstruction preventing CSF flow to the subarachnoid space, making lumbar puncture both dangerous and ineffective for pressure relief.

C) INCORRECT:

Severe headache, altered mental status, and abducens nerve palsy, combined with this patient's CT findings, are consistent with noncommunicating hydrocephalus with increased intracranial pressure (ICP). Fluid resuscitation with hypotonic solutions can worsen cerebral edema and increase ICP. While euvolemia should be maintained, 0.45% NaCl is hypotonic compared to plasma, and large volumes can contribute to brain swelling. Hypertonic saline (e.g., with 3% NaCl) can be given as a temporizing measure in ICP management while arranging definitive therapy.

D) INCORRECT:

Severe headache, altered mental status, and abducens nerve palsy, combined with this patient's CT findings, are consistent with noncommunicating hydrocephalus with increased intracranial pressure. Corticosteroids are indicated for vasogenic edema from specific causes (e.g., tumors, infections), which are unlikely in this patient. Prophylactic antiepileptics are also not routinely recommended for hydrocephalus.

E) INCORRECT:

Severe headache, altered mental status, and abducens nerve palsy, combined with this patient's CT findings, are consistent with noncommunicating hydrocephalus with increased intracranial pressure. While MRI may better characterize an obstructing lesion that is not visible on CT, this patient requires immediate intracranial pressure management. Advanced imaging should be deferred until after the patient is stabilized and should not delay definitive therapy.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman with a history of congenital hydrocephalus and a ventriculoperitoneal shunt presents with a 3-day history of progressive headache, intermittent nausea, and difficulty with balance. She reports that her headaches are worse in the morning and improve slightly when lying down. Her temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), and her neurological examination shows subtle papilledema and mild ataxia. She appears clinically stable with normal vital signs. An MRI brain is shown. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Blood cultures and complete blood count

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

External ventricular drain placement for intracranial pressure monitoring is an invasive procedure typically reserved for severe cases that require continuous monitoring and CSF drainage. In a stable patient with suspected shunt malfunction, the initial priority is assessing the existing shunt's integrity using noninvasive radiographic evaluation before considering invasive monitoring procedures.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- In patients with ventriculoperitoneal shunts presenting with signs of elevated intracranial pressure, shunt series radiographs are the initial diagnostic study to assess catheter continuity, positioning, and integrity along its entire length. This helps identify potential mechanical obstruction, which is a neurosurgical emergency requiring immediate intervention.

C) INCORRECT:

Although shunt infection is a serious complication, this patient's absence of fever and systemic signs of infection makes mechanical obstruction more likely. Shunt integrity should be assessed before pursuing an infectious workup.

D) INCORRECT:

Mannitol is a hyperosmolar therapy used for elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) refractory to conservative measures or if there are signs of brain herniation. For this stable patient with suspected shunt malfunction, the priority is to determine whether the shunt is mechanically intact before initiating medical therapy for elevated ICP.

E) INCORRECT:

In patients with possible elevated intracranial pressure from shunt malfunction, lumbar puncture poses a risk of brain herniation and does not address the underlying problem. CSF analysis may be helpful if a shunt infection is suspected, but this patient's absence of fever and systemic signs of infection make mechanical obstruction more likely.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man with a history of hydrocephalus and ventriculoperitoneal shunt placement 6 months ago presents with a 12-hour history of headache, nausea, and altered mental status. His family reports he was normal 24 hours ago but has become increasingly confused and difficult to arouse. Vital signs are T: 36.8°C (98.2°F); P: 78; BP: 135/82; SpO2 98% on room air. On examination, he is somnolent with slow responses to commands but has no focal neurological deficits. What is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated if there are signs suggestive of elevated intracranial pressure, which this patient has, because it can precipitate brain herniation. If elevated intracranial pressure is suspected, intracranial mass effect should be ruled out with imaging before considering lumbar puncture.

B) INCORRECT:

Shunt series radiographs evaluate shunt placement and integrity but do not assess for the presence of hydrocephalus or other intracranial pathology. Brain imaging to assess for elevated intracranial pressure takes priority in patients with acute neurological deterioration.

C) CORRECT:

Correct – CT head is the most appropriate initial diagnostic test in this patient with suspected shunt malfunction. The rapid onset of altered mental status, headache, and somnolence in a patient with a ventriculoperitoneal shunt strongly suggests shunt obstruction causing elevated intracranial pressure. CT head is sufficient in the acute setting to assess for hydrocephalus and rule out other intracranial pathology.

D) INCORRECT:

An electroencephalogram evaluates electrical brain activity and is used to diagnose seizure disorders, not structural abnormalities or elevated intracranial pressure. This test does not provide information about hydrocephalus or shunt function and would delay appropriate management of suspected shunt malfunction.

E) INCORRECT:

Blood cultures are indicated if infection is suspected; this patient does not have fever or other signs of systemic infection. The acute presentation with altered mental status most likely represents shunt obstruction rather than shunt infection.

questions.text: A 32-year-old patient with a ventriculoperitoneal shunt placed 3 years ago for communicating hydrocephalus presents with progressive headache over 5 days. Vital signs are BP, 130/80; P, 88; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F). Physical examination shows mild confusion and erythema along the subcutaneous portion of the shunt tract. CSF obtained from the shunt reservoir shows 420 cells/mm3 with 68% neutrophils, protein 95 mg/dL, and glucose 35 mg/dL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Shunt obstruction typically manifests with signs of elevated intracranial pressure but not inflammatory markers, which this patient has. The combination of fever, erythema along the shunt tract, and CSF pleocytosis with neutrophil predominance suggests infection rather than mechanical obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

Shunt underdrainage manifests with signs of elevated intracranial pressure but not inflammatory markers, which this patient has. Fever, erythema, and CSF pleocytosis indicate infection rather than inadequate drainage.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The clinical presentation of fever, erythema along the shunt tract, and CSF analysis showing pleocytosis with neutrophil predominance, elevated protein, and decreased glucose is characteristic of shunt infection. This combination of findings indicates bacterial infection that requires immediate neurosurgical consultation.

D) INCORRECT:

Viral meningitis typically manifests with lymphocytic pleocytosis and normal glucose levels. This patient's neutrophil predominance, low glucose, and erythema along the shunt tract are more consistent with bacterial shunt infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Shunt overdrainage leads to intracranial hypotension syndrome and does not typically manifest with fever, erythema, or inflammatory CSF changes. This patient's CSF findings are consistent with bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 72-year-old patient with a history of hypertension presents with progressive headache over 2 days, confusion, and vomiting. The patient appears lethargic with a Glasgow Coma Scale score of 12. Vital signs are BP, 180/100; P, 58; R, 8–12 irregular pattern; oxygen saturation, 89% on room air. The only abnormal CT head finding is shown. Which initial step in management should be prioritized?

choices.text: Supplemental oxygen and head of bed elevation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the patient is vomiting and there is some concern for airway protection, intubation of patients with elevated intracranial pressure (ICP) requires careful consideration of the risks and benefits. Patients with high ICP should not undergo rapid sequence intubation without appropriate pretreatment, as laryngeal manipulation can significantly raise ICP and worsen the clinical condition.

B) INCORRECT:

The CT shows dilated ventricles, indicating acute hydrocephalus. Dexamethasone is only indicated for elevated intracranial pressure caused by vasogenic edema secondary to CNS infection, inflammation, or neoplasms. It is not indicated for acute hydrocephalus without an underlying inflammatory or neoplastic process.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with acute hydrocephalus with elevated intracranial pressure due to the risk of precipitating brain herniation. The dilated ventricles on CT indicate obstructive hydrocephalus requiring neurosurgical intervention.

D) CORRECT:

Correct – The CT shows dilated ventricles consistent with acute hydrocephalus, and this patient has clinical features of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). This patient has significant hypoxia requiring immediate supplemental oxygen to prevent secondary brain injury. Head of bed elevation to approximately 30° can reduce ICP without compromising cerebral blood flow. Safe temporizing measures for ICP management are indicated while expediting definitive neurosurgical CSF drainage (e.g., external ventricular drain placement or ventriculoperitoneal shunting).

E) INCORRECT:

The CT shows dilated ventricles, and this patient has clinical features of elevated intracranial pressure (ICP). Aggressive antihypertensive therapy could compromise cerebral perfusion pressure in a patient with elevated ICP. Blood pressure management requires careful consideration of the relationship between systemic blood pressure and ICP.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of fever, headache, and nausea. She had a ventriculoperitoneal shunt placed 25 years ago for congenital hydrocephalus. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), and neurological examination shows no focal deficits. CT head shows no acute changes. CSF obtained from the shunt reservoir shows a WBC count of 250/mm3 with 85% neutrophils, elevated protein, and decreased glucose. Neurosurgery has been consulted for shunt removal. What is the most appropriate empiric antibiotic therapy while awaiting culture results?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone alone does not provide adequate coverage against methicillin-resistant variants of gram-positive bacteria, such as Staphylococcus epidermidis, which are a common cause of shunt infections.

B) CORRECT:

Correct – Vancomycin provides coverage for methicillin-resistant variants of gram-positive organisms, such as Staphylococcus epidermidis, which are a common cause of shunt infections. An additional antipseudomonal beta-lactam (e.g., ceftazidime, cefepime, or meropenem) is recommended to cover gram-negative bacteria.

C) INCORRECT:

Ampicillin and gentamicin do not provide optimal coverage for the staphylococcal species that predominantly cause shunt infections. Gentamicin has limited CSF penetration and is not recommended empirically for CNS infection in adults, although it is indicated to treat neonatal meningitis because it covers species that cause neonatal sepsis (e.g., Enterococcus).

D) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin and ciprofloxacin do not provide the broad-spectrum coverage needed for a suspected shunt infection. Clindamycin has poor gram-negative coverage and poor CNS penetration. Ciprofloxacin does provide extensive gram-negative coverage, including for Pseudomonas, which is important in health care-associated infections. However, neither of these antibiotics provides reliable coverage for methicillin-resistant staphylococci, which commonly cause neurosurgical device infections.

E) INCORRECT:

While meropenem has broad-spectrum activity, monotherapy does not provide reliable coverage against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus epidermidis, which is a common cause of shunt infections.
